Hi,

This is "expected" behaviour as stated in this comment in the code.

I added more details in the forum for why it happens in your particular case.
The right solution here is:

  • detach() tensors in your hook function if you don't need gradients flowing back.
  • explicitly del a, b after doing all the forward and backward you want to do through the hooks.

body:
Hi,

This is "expected" behaviour as stated in [this comment](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/25f4b3efe355c9d7d2d9341f818b8616cbb5435b/torch/csrc/autograd/python_variable.cpp#L81-L94) in the code.

I added more details in the forum for why it happens in your particular case.
The right solution here is:
- `detach()` tensors in your hook function if you don't need gradients flowing back.
- explicitly `del a, b` after doing all the forward and backward you want to do through the hooks.
